text.p: These are the leading stories in the Pakistani press on Thursday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Parliament adopted the Anti-Terrorism Act 1997 giving sweeping powers to law enforcing agencies.
- Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif assured the opposition that the law against terrorism is not based on mala fide intentions nor will it be used as a weapon against political opponents.
- Minister for Law and Human Rights Khalid Anwar said the government might clamp a ban on religious schools as he said they teach terrorism instead of the Koran.
- A bomb exploded in the residential premises of Chief Secretary Northern Areas in Gilgit. No loss of life or property was reported except for burning of a tent.
- Four armed men shot dead three others in a dispute over the kidnapping of a married woman.
- The investment policy is expected to provide a fresh package of incentives to export processing and free trade zones.
- The Human Rights Commission of Pakistan has termed the anti-terrorism law an instrument likely to strike terror in the hearts of the common man rather than deter terrorists.
- After staging a walkout from the National Assembly (lower house) against the passage of the anti-terrorism bill, the Pakistan People's Party hinted at a possible court challenge.

- Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif said the death penalty for terrorists will discourage others from committing heinous crimes. The speedy trial courts to deal exclusively with cases of terrorism will start functioning on Friday.
- Sharif has declared a jihad (holy war) against inimical forces and vowed to make the country strong and prosperous.
- The State (central) Bank of Pakistan permitted foreign banks in Pakistan to invest in corporate fixed income securities.
